body: Concept ACK
Tests are failing on the latest commit. Looking in to it.
doh!
[Squash needed](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits) at some point.

Nice. Concept ACK.
Travis is failing because of the subtree change that is separately opened in https://github.com/bitcoin-core/univalue/pull/12

My attempt to squash this seems to have gone awfully wrong. Trying to fix it up...

edit: should be fine now.
Related: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/2960
(travis failure is due to subtree check for univalue)

<!--5d09a71f8925f3f132321140b44b946d-->The last travis run for this pull request was 151 days ago and is thus outdated. To trigger a fresh travis build, this pull request should be closed and re-opened.
<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->Needs rebase
Closing this for now, and adding "up for grabs" tag. Let me know if you want to start work on this again and I'll reopen…
univalue changes need to be submitted upstream, not here :)
He did that (see OP).

I commented in the [univalue PR](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/univalue/pull/12) that this catch should probably be for a derived class of `std::exception`, not `int`. If this is the case, there will be no need to re-throw, as the std:exception handler will catch all else below.
Yes, throwing an int is really weird.
Does this create different behavior for degenerate returns when not passing `-strictjsonrpcspec`?
Could just do `std::string strReply(ret.write() + "\n");`

diff_hunk:
@@ -21,11 +21,18 @@
  *
  * 1.0 spec: http://json-rpc.org/wiki/specification
  * 1.2 spec: http://jsonrpc.org/historical/json-rpc-over-http.html
+ *
+ * By passing -strictjsonrpcspec one can force Bitcoin to speak strict 2.0.
+ *
  */
 
+bool fStrictJSONRPCSpec = false;
body: Should this have some kind of `g` prefix given it's a global? Also, may want to use snake_case.

These exception constructors are usually made `explicit` to prevent implicit conversion. You can see [uint_error](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/arith_uint256.h#L18-L21) as an example.
Are you sure this univalue API change is really necessary? You could find out if the key is there with an additional call to `Univalue::exists`? (or am I missing something)

diff_hunk:
@@ -21,11 +21,18 @@
  *
  * 1.0 spec: http://json-rpc.org/wiki/specification
  * 1.2 spec: http://jsonrpc.org/historical/json-rpc-over-http.html
+ *
+ * By passing -strictjsonrpcspec one can force Bitcoin to speak strict 2.0.
+ *
  */
 
+bool fStrictJSONRPCSpec = false;
body: Yes, should be `g_strict_jsonrpc_spec` or such w/ the new guidelines.
